title: 10,325 Robots Ordered in One Quarter. $579 Million.
body:
In Q4 2025, North American companies ordered 10,325 industrial robots worth $579 million. That is a 6.6% jump from the year before.

Automotive led the surge. Major vehicle manufacturers are finally stabilizing after years of supply chain chaos. But here is the twist -- non-automotive orders are growing even faster. Food, pharma, logistics. Everyone wants robots now.

The companies building these machines? Fanuc (FANUY), ABB, Rockwell (ROK). They are not guessing about demand. They are filling orders.

Robot density in the US is still half of South Korea's. We are early.

title: Rockwell Just Beat Earnings by 10.7%. Then Announced a Factory of the Future.
body:
Rockwell Automation just dropped Q4 results. Adjusted EPS: $2.75 vs $2.48 expected. That is a 10.7% beat.

Adjusted EBITDA hit $513 million -- a 24.4% margin.

Then they announced a 1-million-square-foot factory in New Berlin, Wisconsin. Largest Rockwell campus on Earth. Part of a $2 billion bet on domestic manufacturing over 5 years.

The company that builds the brains for every assembly line in America just said: we are going bigger than ever.

title: How a Single Machine Fills 2,000 Cans Per Minute
body:
A modern canning line fills 2,000 aluminum cans every 60 seconds. That is 33 per second.

The can arrives empty. A filler valve opens for exactly 0.12 seconds, dispensing the precise volume. Then a lid is placed and seamed shut with two mechanical rolls -- one tucks the edge, the second crimps it airtight. The whole seal takes 0.08 seconds.

Every can gets hit with a camera inspection system checking fill level, lid placement, and date code. One bad can and the whole batch gets flagged.

Ball Corporation makes most of the cans. Ticker BALL. $14 billion company built on a piece of aluminum thinner than a credit card.

title: Industrial AI is a $184 Billion Market. Most People Have No Idea.
body:
The global industrial automation market hit $184.4 billion in 2025. It is projected to reach $326 billion by 2032.

That is not consumer AI. Not chatbots. Not image generators.

This is AI that runs factories. Predictive maintenance that catches a bearing failure 3 weeks before it happens. Vision systems that inspect 500 parts per minute with zero human fatigue. Autonomous mobile robots that reroute themselves when a forklift blocks the aisle.

The companies winning this? Nvidia for the compute. Rockwell for the controls. Honeywell for the process side.

Everyone is talking about AI replacing office workers. Nobody is talking about AI replacing $47/hour maintenance techs. That is where the real money is.

title: The Machine That Sorts 400,000 Packages Per Hour
body:
Amazon's latest sortation centers process 400,000 packages per hour. Per. Hour.

A package hits the conveyor. A 3D scanner reads its dimensions and barcode in milliseconds. An AI routing engine assigns it to one of 1,200 destination chutes. Then a series of diverters -- mechanical arms that fire with pneumatic precision -- kick it off the belt at exactly the right moment.

Miss the timing by 50 milliseconds and the package ends up in the wrong zip code.

The conveyors run at 500 feet per minute. The whole system draws enough power to run 2,000 homes. And it replaced what used to take 3,000 human sorters per shift.

title: SICK Sensors: The Eyes Inside Every Machine You Use
body:
Every time you buy something off a conveyor, open a car door, or drink from a bottle -- a SICK sensor probably inspected it first.

SICK AG makes the photoelectric sensors, LiDAR, vision cameras, and safety systems that run inside nearly every automated factory on Earth. 12,000+ employees. 53,000+ products.

Their safety light curtains protect workers' hands near presses. Their barcode readers sort 10,000 packages per minute at FedEx. Their 3D vision systems guide robot arms to pick the right part every time.

Most investors have never heard of them. Frankfurt ticker SY1. They do not need your attention. The machines already depend on them.
